hook.text: Milton Friedman said a company's only duty is to make money for shareholders. Full stop.

buildup.text: For decades, Friedman's 1970 doctrine dominated business schools: profit is the sole social responsibility.

discovery.text: Edward Freeman flipped this. Stakeholder theory says companies owe duties to employees, communities, and the planet.

twist.text: In 2019, 181 CEOs signed a statement rejecting shareholder primacy. Critics called it empty PR.

climax.text: The debate isn't settled. When profit and people clash, most boards still choose the quarterly earnings report.

punchline.text: Shareholders or stakeholders? Follow the money for the real answer.

quiz.question: What does stakeholder theory argue about corporate responsibility?
options: Companies should only maximize shareholder profit
Companies owe duties to employees, communities, and the environment
Companies should avoid making any profit

hook.text: A company follows every law perfectly and still poisons a river. Legal? Yes. Ethical? That's the gap.

buildup.text: Compliance means following rules. Ethics means doing rightâ€”even when no rule requires it.

discovery.text: Laws set the floor. Ethics sets the ceiling. Most corporate scandals happen in the space between.

twist.text: Companies spend billions on compliance departments but often treat ethics training as a checkbox exercise.

climax.text: Enron had a 64-page code of ethics. It won awards for it. Then it committed the largest fraud in US history.

punchline.text: A rulebook on the shelf isn't ethics. It's furniture.

quiz.question: What is the key difference between ethics and compliance?
options: They mean exactly the same thing
Compliance follows laws; ethics goes beyond legal requirements to do what's right
Ethics only applies to individuals, not companies

hook.text: When BP spilled oil in the Gulf, we blamed 'BP.' But BP is a legal fiction. Paper can't feel guilt.

buildup.text: Corporations have legal personhoodâ€”they can sue, own property, and sign contracts. But can they be moral?

discovery.text: Peter French argued yes: corporate structures create intentions beyond any individual employee's choices.

twist.text: Critics counter: only humans feel remorse. Corporate 'apologies' are written by PR teams calculating damage control.

climax.text: If corporations aren't moral agents, can we ethically punish them? Or should we only punish the humans inside?

punchline.text: We gave corporations rights. The duties are still debatable.

quiz.question: What did philosopher Peter French argue about corporations?
options: Corporations can never have any moral responsibility
Corporate structures create collective intentions that make them moral agents
Only shareholders bear moral responsibility for corporate actions

topics.title: Codes of Ethics That Actually Work

hook.text: 90% of Fortune 500 companies have ethics codes. Less than half of employees can name a single rule in them.

buildup.text: A code of ethics outlines principles and expected behavior. Most gather dust in HR filing cabinets.

discovery.text: Effective codes are short, specific, and backed by leadership who visibly follow them. Example matters more than text.

twist.text: Johnson & Johnson's credo guided their 1982 Tylenol recallâ€”pulling $100M in product to protect consumers.

climax.text: The difference: J&J's leaders used their code in a crisis. Most companies frame theirs and forget it.

punchline.text: A code works when the CEO follows it on the worst day.

quiz.question: What makes a corporate code of ethics effective?
options: Making it as long and detailed as possible
Leadership visibly following it, especially during crises
Keeping it secret from most employees

hook.text: In 1906, a novel about meatpacking was so disgusting that the president read it and changed the law.

buildup.text: Upton Sinclair's 'The Jungle' exposed rotting meat sold to consumers. The FDA was born from public outrage.

discovery.text: Business regulation follows a pattern: scandal, public fury, new law. Repeat every few decades.

twist.text: After each wave of regulation, industries lobby to weaken the rules. Deregulation caused the 2008 financial crash.

climax.text: Regulation is a pendulumâ€”too little breeds exploitation, too much stifles growth. The balance is never permanent.

punchline.text: Every major regulation has a horror story behind it.

quiz.question: What pattern does business regulation historically follow?
options: Gradual, steady improvement without any triggering events
Corporate scandal, public outrage, then new regulation
Businesses voluntarily regulate themselves before any problems occur

hook.text: In 1953, a book asked: what does business owe society? Corporate social responsibility was born.

buildup.text: Howard Bowen argued businessmen are stewards of public resources and must consider social consequences.

discovery.text: CSR evolved from charity in the 1960s to strategic sustainability programs worth billions today.

twist.text: Critics say CSR is just marketing. Companies donate millions publicly while lobbying against regulation privately.

climax.text: Modern CSR is a spectrumâ€”from genuine commitment to cynical window dressing. Telling them apart is the challenge.

punchline.text: Good deeds make great ads. Intent is harder to measure.

quiz.question: Who is considered the father of corporate social responsibility?
options: Milton Friedman
Howard Bowen
Adam Smith

hook.text: A hotel asks you to reuse towels 'to save the planet.' Their real motive? Saving on laundry costs.

buildup.text: Greenwashing is when companies exaggerate or fake environmental efforts to appear sustainable.

discovery.text: Common tactics: vague claims like 'eco-friendly,' green packaging on dirty products, and cherry-picked data.

twist.text: Volkswagen marketed 'clean diesel' cars while secretly installing software to cheat emissions tests.

climax.text: Greenwashing doesn't just deceive consumers. It undermines companies actually investing in real sustainability.

punchline.text: Green paint is cheaper than green practices.

quiz.question: What is greenwashing?
options: A method of cleaning products with eco-friendly chemicals
Exaggerating or faking environmental efforts to appear sustainable
A government program to fund green businesses

hook.text: What if a company's legal charter required it to help the world, not just make money?

buildup.text: B Corps are businesses certified to meet high standards of social and environmental performance.

discovery.text: Unlike regular corporations, B Corps legally commit to considering workers, community, and environment in decisions.

twist.text: Patagonia became a B Corp and even told customers 'Don't Buy This Jacket'â€”profits still soared.

climax.text: Critics question if certification is rigorous enough. Some B Corps still outsource to low-wage factories.

punchline.text: A better label for business. The proof is in the supply chain.

quiz.question: What makes B Corps different from traditional corporations?
options: They are exempt from paying taxes
They legally commit to social and environmental performance standards
They cannot earn a profit

hook.text: Your $5 t-shirt was made by someone earning $3 a day. The brand says it's not their factory, not their problem.

buildup.text: Global supply chains stretch across dozens of countries, subcontractors, and sub-subcontractors.

discovery.text: The 2013 Rana Plaza collapse in Bangladesh killed 1,134 garment workers. Major Western brands sourced there.

twist.text: Companies claimed ignoranceâ€”but their auditors had flagged the building's cracks months earlier.

climax.text: Are brands responsible for conditions ten layers deep in their supply chain? Legally, often no. Ethically?

punchline.text: You can outsource labor. You can't outsource responsibility.

quiz.question: What did the Rana Plaza collapse reveal about global supply chains?
options: Western brands had no connection to Bangladeshi factories
Brands sourced from unsafe factories despite audit warnings
Supply chain conditions had improved dramatically by 2013

hook.text: A mining company had every government permit. The local community blocked the road anyway. Operations halted.

buildup.text: Social license to operate means a community's informal acceptance that a company can do business there.

discovery.text: It's not a legal document. It's earned through trust, transparency, and genuine benefit to the community.

twist.text: Shell learned this in Nigeria. Legal permits meant nothing when local communities united against oil extraction.

climax.text: Companies that ignore social license face protests, boycotts, and delays that cost more than compliance ever would.

punchline.text: A permit comes from government. Permission comes from people.

quiz.question: What is a 'social license to operate'?
options: A government-issued business permit
A community's informal acceptance that a company can operate in their area
A type of corporate insurance policy

hook.text: Identical resumes. One name: Emily. Other name: Lakisha. Emily got 50% more callbacks.

buildup.text: A landmark 2003 study proved what minorities already knew: names alone trigger hiring discrimination.

discovery.text: Workplace discrimination isn't always overt. Unconscious bias shapes who gets hired, promoted, and heard.

twist.text: Diversity training became a $8 billion industry, but meta-analyses show most programs have little lasting effect.

climax.text: Structural changesâ€”blind resume reviews, diverse hiring panelsâ€”work better than teaching people to 'not be biased.'

punchline.text: You can't train bias away. You can design it out.

quiz.question: What approach is most effective at reducing workplace discrimination?
options: Structural changes like blind resume reviews and diverse panels
Mandatory diversity training alone
Ignoring the issue and hoping it resolves itself

hook.text: A CEO screamed at employees daily. Revenue was up 40%. The board called him 'passionate.' Turnover was 70%.

buildup.text: Toxic leaders use fear, humiliation, and manipulation. They deliver short-term results at long-term human cost.

discovery.text: Research shows toxic leadership costs US companies $24 billion annually in turnover, lawsuits, and lost productivity.

twist.text: Boards tolerate toxic leaders when profits are high. The damage only surfaces after the leader leavesâ€”or gets sued.

climax.text: Uber's Travis Kalanick drove explosive growth and a culture so toxic it nearly destroyed the company.

punchline.text: A leader who breaks people to hit numbers isn't leading. They're looting.

quiz.question: Why do boards often tolerate toxic leaders?
options: Toxic behavior always improves company culture
They deliver short-term financial results that mask long-term damage
Employees actually prefer aggressive leadership styles

hook.text: Your employer tracks your keystrokes, screenshots your screen every 10 minutes, and monitors your bathroom breaks.

buildup.text: Remote work triggered a surveillance boom. 'Bossware' software monitors everything employees do on company devices.

discovery.text: Companies claim surveillance boosts productivity. Studies show it actually increases stress and decreases trust.

twist.text: In most US states, employers can legally monitor almost everything without telling employees. Consent isn't required.

climax.text: The EU takes a different approachâ€”GDPR requires proportionality and transparency in any workplace monitoring.

punchline.text: Watching people work doesn't make them work better. It makes them leave.

quiz.question: What do studies show about the effect of employee surveillance on productivity?
options: It significantly increases both productivity and morale
It increases stress and decreases trust without boosting real output
It has no measurable effect on workplace behavior

hook.text: A DoorDash driver earns $4 per delivery, pays for gas, has no health insurance, and can be deactivated in seconds.

buildup.text: Gig companies classify workers as independent contractorsâ€”no benefits, no minimum wage, no unemployment insurance.

discovery.text: This saves companies up to 30% in labor costs while shifting all financial risk onto the workers.

twist.text: California passed AB5 to reclassify gig workers. Uber and Lyft spent $200 million on Prop 22 to reverse it.

climax.text: The gig economy thrives on a loophole: calling employees contractors. Courts are slowly closing that gap.

punchline.text: Flexibility for workers or exploitation by design? Depends on who's profiting.

quiz.question: Why do gig companies prefer classifying workers as independent contractors?
options: It gives workers better benefits and protections
It saves up to 30% in labor costs by avoiding benefits and protections
Independent contractors earn higher wages than employees

hook.text: Your boss emails you at 11pm. You answer. Every night. You're not paid overtime. This is 'just culture.'

buildup.text: Smartphones erased the boundary between work and life. Many employees feel always on-call, never truly off.

discovery.text: France passed a Right to Disconnect law in 2017, letting employees ignore work emails after hours without penalty.

twist.text: Enforcement is weak. Companies follow the letter but not the spiritâ€”sending 'FYI' emails that clearly expect replies.

climax.text: Australia, Spain, and Portugal followed France. The US has no such law. After-hours emails remain the norm.

punchline.text: If you can't stop working, you don't have a job. It has you.

quiz.question: What does France's Right to Disconnect law allow employees to do?
options: Work from home permanently without employer approval
Ignore work communications after hours without penalty
Quit their job without giving any notice

hook.text: Martha Stewart sold stock the day before bad news broke. She made $45,000. She spent five months in prison.

buildup.text: Insider trading means buying or selling stock based on confidential information the public doesn't have yet.

discovery.text: It's illegal because markets depend on fairness. If insiders always win, ordinary investors stop playing.

twist.text: Members of Congress traded stocks during COVID briefings before the public knew how bad things were. Few faced charges.

climax.text: Laws ban insider trading, but enforcement is selective. The powerful often trade on privilege and call it 'timing.'

punchline.text: When everyone cheats, trust is the first thing sold.

quiz.question: Why is insider trading illegal?
options: It causes stock prices to rise too quickly
It gives unfair advantage using non-public information, undermining market trust
It is too profitable for the government to tax

hook.text: Bernie Madoff delivered steady 12% returns for 20 years. Not one trade was ever made. $65 billion vanished.

buildup.text: A Ponzi scheme pays old investors with new investors' money. There's no real profitâ€”just a transfer chain.

discovery.text: It works as long as new money flows in. The moment withdrawals exceed deposits, the whole structure collapses.

twist.text: Harry Markopolos warned the SEC about Madoff for nine years. They investigated and found nothing. Twice.

climax.text: Madoff's scheme lasted so long because his returns looked boringly consistent. The best cons don't look exciting.

punchline.text: If returns seem too steady, someone's making them up.

quiz.question: How does a Ponzi scheme generate 'returns' for investors?
options: Through high-frequency stock trading algorithms
By paying existing investors with money from new investors
By investing in high-risk international markets

hook.text: A CEO earns $25 million a year. The median worker at the same company earns $35,000. That's a 714:1 ratio.

buildup.text: In 1965, CEO-to-worker pay ratio was 21:1. By 2023, it exceeded 340:1 on average at top US firms.

discovery.text: Executive pay is set by boards filled with other executives. It's a club that keeps raising its own prices.

twist.text: Stock options aimed to align CEO interests with shareholders. Instead, CEOs pump short-term prices and cash out.

climax.text: Meanwhile, real wages for workers have barely kept pace with inflation for forty years.

punchline.text: Performance pay for executives. Flat pay for everyone else.

quiz.question: How did the CEO-to-worker pay ratio change from 1965 to 2023?
options: It decreased from 100:1 to 21:1
It stayed roughly the same at about 50:1
It grew from 21:1 to over 340:1

hook.text: Apple earned $74 billion overseas and paid almost no tax on it. Illegal? No. That's the problem.

buildup.text: Tax evasion is illegalâ€”hiding income or lying on returns. Tax avoidance is legalâ€”exploiting loopholes in the code.

discovery.text: Companies use shell companies, transfer pricing, and tax havens to shift profits to low-tax jurisdictions legally.

twist.text: The countries losing tax revenue are the same ones providing roads, courts, and educated workers these companies use.

climax.text: In 2021, 136 countries agreed to a 15% global minimum corporate tax. Enforcement remains the hard part.

punchline.text: Legal and ethical aren't synonyms. Especially in tax law.

quiz.question: What is the difference between tax avoidance and tax evasion?
options: There is no difference; both are illegal
Tax avoidance exploits legal loopholes; tax evasion is illegal
Tax evasion is legal; tax avoidance is illegal

hook.text: An ESG fund labeled 'sustainable' held stock in oil companies, weapons makers, and a private prison firm.

buildup.text: ESG investing rates companies on environmental, social, and governance factors to guide ethical investment.

discovery.text: ESG assets hit $35 trillion globally. Investors want profit and purpose. But who defines 'good'?

twist.text: Rating agencies score the same company wildly differently. Tesla is ESG-great or ESG-terrible depending who you ask.

climax.text: Without standardized metrics, ESG risks becoming another form of greenwashingâ€”good labels on murky realities.

punchline.text: Ethical investing is a $35 trillion question with no agreed answer.

quiz.question: What is a major criticism of ESG investing?
options: It always delivers lower returns than traditional investing
Different rating agencies score the same companies inconsistently
No investors are interested in ESG criteria

hook.text: Sherron Watkins warned Enron's CEO about fraud. She was sidelined. He went to prison. She lost her career.

buildup.text: Whistleblowers expose wrongdoing from inside organizationsâ€”fraud, safety violations, corruption.

discovery.text: Edward Snowden revealed NSA mass surveillance. Daniel Ellsberg leaked the Pentagon Papers. Both changed history.

twist.text: Almost every famous whistleblower paid a devastating personal priceâ€”exile, firing, lawsuits, or social isolation.

climax.text: Society celebrates whistleblowers after the fact but punishes them in real time. The pattern never changes.

punchline.text: Heroes in the history books. Pariahs in the break room.

quiz.question: What typically happens to whistleblowers in the short term?
options: They receive immediate promotions and praise
They face retaliation, job loss, and social isolation
They are always protected by comprehensive legal shields

hook.text: A nurse reports unsafe staffing levels. She's fired within a month. The hospital calls it 'restructuring.'

buildup.text: The US has over 50 whistleblower protection laws, each covering different industries and types of misconduct.

discovery.text: The Dodd-Frank Act lets SEC whistleblowers earn 10-30% of sanctions over $1 million. Some earned hundreds of millions.

twist.text: Financial rewards work. But most industries offer no bountyâ€”just a promise not to fire you that's hard to enforce.

climax.text: Proving retaliation is on the whistleblower. Legal battles take years. Most people can't afford the fight.

punchline.text: The law protects whistleblowers on paper. Reality is more expensive.

quiz.question: What incentive does the Dodd-Frank Act provide for SEC whistleblowers?
options: Guaranteed lifetime employment protection
10-30% of sanctions collected over $1 million
Automatic immunity from all criminal prosecution

hook.text: First they question your work. Then your sanity. Then your loyalty. Then you're gone. The script never changes.

buildup.text: Retaliation against whistleblowers follows predictable stages: isolation, discrediting, demotion, termination.

discovery.text: Studies show 83% of whistleblowers face some form of retaliation. Organizations punish the messenger instinctively.

twist.text: Retaliation often comes from colleagues, not just bosses. Co-workers fear guilt by association or team disruption.

climax.text: The chilling effect is the real damage. For every person who speaks up, dozens stay silent after watching what happens.

punchline.text: Retaliation doesn't just punish one person. It silences a thousand.

quiz.question: What is the 'chilling effect' of whistleblower retaliation?
options: It makes office temperatures uncomfortable
Seeing retaliation silences potential future whistleblowers
It reduces company profits temporarily

hook.text: A tip line receives a call: the CFO is cooking the books. The caller? Nobody knows. That's the point.

buildup.text: Anonymous hotlines and reporting platforms let employees flag misconduct without revealing their identity.

discovery.text: ACFE data shows tips detect 43% of corporate fraudâ€”more than audits, management review, or any other method.

twist.text: But anonymity has limits. Small teams can guess who reported. Some companies even use tip lines to find dissenters.

climax.text: The best systems use third-party operators, encrypted channels, and anti-retaliation audits to protect callers.

punchline.text: The best fraud detector isn't software. It's a safe phone line.

quiz.question: According to ACFE data, what is the most effective method for detecting corporate fraud?
options: External financial audits
Management review and oversight
Tips from anonymous reporting systems

hook.text: Enron was named 'America's Most Innovative Company' six years in a row. It was all a lie.

buildup.text: Enron used off-balance-sheet entities to hide $38 billion in debt while reporting record profits to investors.

discovery.text: Executives sold stock quietly while pushing employees to invest their entire retirement savings in Enron shares.

twist.text: Arthur Andersen, their auditorâ€”supposed to be the watchdogâ€”shredded documents to cover up the fraud.

climax.text: 20,000 employees lost jobs and pensions. Andersen collapsed. Congress passed Sarbanes-Oxley to prevent a repeat.

punchline.text: Innovation without integrity isn't progress. It's a time bomb.

quiz.question: What role did Arthur Andersen play in the Enron scandal?
options: They discovered and reported the fraud to regulators
They were Enron's auditor and helped cover up the fraud
They were a competing energy company

hook.text: A child in Vietnam stitches Nike shoes for 20 cents an hour. An economist says this is 'better than the alternative.'

buildup.text: Sweatshops pay extremely low wages in poor conditions. Millions of workers in developing countries depend on them.

discovery.text: Critics demand boycotts and shutdowns. But some economists argue sweatshop jobs beat subsistence farming or starvation.

twist.text: That 'least bad option' argument ignores a third choice: paying workers fairly while still earning profit.

climax.text: The real question isn't sweatshops vs nothing. It's why companies earning billions can't pay a living wage.

punchline.text: Cheap for consumers. Cheap for workers. Expensive for conscience.

quiz.question: What does the sweatshop debate often overlook?
options: That sweatshop workers enjoy their conditions
The possibility of paying fair wages while still remaining profitable
That no alternatives to sweatshop labor exist

hook.text: Siemens paid $1.4 billion in bribes across 30 countries. They had a department for it. With a budget.

buildup.text: The Foreign Corrupt Practices Act bans US companies from bribing foreign officials. The UK Bribery Act goes further.

discovery.text: Transparency International ranks countries by corruption. In many nations, bribery isn't a scandal. It's standard.

twist.text: Companies claim they can't compete without bribing. But corruption costs the global economy 5% of GDP every year.

climax.text: Anti-bribery enforcement is growing, but only 4 of 44 OECD countries actively enforce their own laws.

punchline.text: The cost of corruption isn't the bribe. It's everything it breaks.

quiz.question: What does the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act prohibit?
options: All forms of international trade
US companies from bribing foreign government officials
Foreign companies from doing business in the United States

hook.text: In one country, a gift to a partner is polite. In another, it's a felony. Same action, different ethics.

buildup.text: Cultural relativism says moral standards vary by society. What's ethical depends on where you are.

discovery.text: Multinational companies face this daily: follow home country ethics, or adapt to local norms?

twist.text: Taken too far, relativism excuses anything. Child labor, discrimination, corruptionâ€”all justified as 'their culture.'

climax.text: Most ethicists seek a middle ground: respect cultural differences but maintain universal minimum standards.

punchline.text: Culture explains behavior. It doesn't always excuse it.

quiz.question: What is the risk of applying cultural relativism too broadly in business?
options: It makes international trade impossible
It can justify harmful practices like child labor as culturally acceptable
It forces all countries to adopt identical laws

hook.text: You pay $2 extra for fair-trade coffee. The farmer gets 5 cents more. Where did the rest go?

buildup.text: Fair trade guarantees minimum prices and better conditions for producers in developing countries.

discovery.text: Studies confirm fair-trade farmers earn more and invest in schools and clinics. The model worksâ€”at small scale.

twist.text: But fair trade captures under 1% of global trade. Most premium goes to middlemen and retailers, not farmers.

climax.text: Critics call it a feel-good niche. Defenders say even partial justice beats the alternative of none.

punchline.text: Fair trade helps some. Fixing trade helps all. We chose the easy one.

quiz.question: What is a key limitation of the fair trade model?
options: It makes products cheaper for consumers
It captures less than 1% of global trade and most premiums go to middlemen
Farmers refuse to participate in fair trade programs

hook.text: Google earned $20 billion in revenue from Australia. It paid less tax there than a local coffee shop chain.

buildup.text: Multinationals use transfer pricingâ€”charging subsidiaries for internal servicesâ€”to shift profit to tax havens.

discovery.text: Ireland, Luxembourg, and the Netherlands became corporate tax havens, attracting trillions in paper profits.

twist.text: Developing nations lose $200 billion yearly to corporate tax avoidanceâ€”more than they receive in foreign aid.

climax.text: The 2021 global minimum tax deal aims to end the race to the bottom. But loopholes are already being found.

punchline.text: Global companies, local loopholes. The profits vanish into thin air.

quiz.question: How do multinationals use transfer pricing to reduce taxes?
options: By paying employees in different currencies
By charging internal subsidiaries to shift profits to low-tax jurisdictions
By donating profits to charity in every country they operate in
